#Text=Canada 's Don Valley East ( Ward 33 ) city council candidates speak
#Text=Saturday , November 4 , 2006
#Text=On November 13 , Torontonians will be heading to the polls to vote for their ward 's councillor and for mayor .
#Text=Among Toronto 's ridings is Don Valley East ( Ward 33 ) .
#Text=One candidates responded to Wikinews ' requests for an interview .
#Text=This ward 's candidates include Zane Caplan , Shelley Carroll ( incumbent ) , Jim Conlon , Sarah Tsang-Fahey , and Anderson Tung .
#Text=For more information on the election , read Toronto municipal election , 2006 .
#Text=Shelley Carroll ( incumbent )
#Text=49-year-old Shelley Carroll is the incumbent for Don Valley East , Ward 33 , and has served either in this position or as a school board trustee for the last decade .
#Text=More information can be found on her website , or her blog .
#Text=Q : Describe the three most important issues in your campaign .
#Text=A : Locally , completing a storm-water retention system for North York 's flooded areas .
#Text=Controlling and mitigating the impacts of subway-induced development .
#Text=Globally , completing a long-term solid-waste strategy for the city of Toronto .
#Text=A comprehensive environmental assessment process has already been launched , under my leadership of the Works committee and I intend to see it through .
#Text=Q : What one election issue do you feel is most relevant to your ward in this election ?
#Text=A : Part of mitigating development impact is bringing about better traffic and transit management .
#Text=Residents of Don Valley East are passionate about both these elements of city life .
#Text=Q : Why have you chosen to involve yourself in the political process ?
#Text=A : I entered politics in 1995 , concerned about a better education system and ultimately a better City for my own children .
#Text=I felt that a better future for them could only be achieved by building a stronger community for everyone .
#Text=After 10 years , I find the work constant but endlessly rewarding .
#Text=Q : Why do you want to represent this particular ward on council ?
#Text=A : Ward 33 always feels like a microcosm of the whole City of Toronto to me .
#Text=Residents of all backgrounds are engaged in civic issues like never before .
#Text=They they [ sic ] want a city that supports the next generation economically and socially , and we need a City that supports their hard work .
#Text=Q : How are you currently involved in the community ?
#Text=A : Serving first as a School Board Trustee and now as City Councillor has spread my community involvement across a broad range of activities .
#Text=I visit and participate in multi-cultural seniors organizations , childrens ' service providers , and residents ' associations .
#Text=I have created two new additions to the list of resident/ratepayer associations as well as running my own Ward Advisory Council .
#Text=Q : What does Toronto mean to you ?
#Text=A : Toronto is at the edge of becoming the North American City that shows all of the others how to grow without compromising the quality of life and the environment .
#Text=The decisions we make will serve as an example of how a progressive city should act .
#Text=Our Youth Strategy , which I helped author , asks that we never create another City initiative without asking if we are leaving youth or the marginalized behind .
#Text=As Works Committee Chair , I always ask , " How does this benefit the environment ?
